titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to Dedham again early this morning; but neither of the reports upon our roads were made. The whole day was employed in the trial of an indictment against Philip Wentworth and John Garraux, for oversetting a Chaise of two young men by the names of Davis and Glover— The parties all belong to Boston— Charles Paine came to support the complainants and Everett for the defts:— He also engaged me for them in Court— The trial was long, as the witnesses were numerous; but the case was very simple, and little was to be said upon it— I staid untill after sunset, when the jury had not return’d their verdict— Had some conversation with J. Gardner who was there— Return’d to Boston, and found almost all the family sick— The Child has been ill, and growing more ill for several days past— Cutting teeth— This day and evening he was very ill— Mrs: Adams has fatigued and distress’d herself so much with him, that she was seized with great violence just at bed-time— Sent for Dr: Welsh, who composed her with laudanum— I was up with them untill after 1 in the morning— Caroline was likewise very ill, and obliged to take to her bed.

2. At the Office of the Commissioners of bankrupts, upon a further adjournment of Roylance Child’s third meeting— Adjourn’d again to 4 November— Rest of the forenoon at my Office.— My mother came to town this morning, and I went out to Quincy with her this afternoon— Mr: Babcock conversed with me, on the subject of the approaching election— He urged me not to refuse standing as a candidate for this district— But I ought not to stand in Mr: Quincy’s way, and he was held up at the last election.

3. Read two treatises of Plutarch— One, that a prince ought to be learned— The other, a fragment, on the position that Vice alone is productive of misery— Heard a Mr: Howard, a very good preacher— Mr: W. Cranch dined with us— Consulted Horace to find a quotation in my brother’s last letter, and found the Ode 4. book 2. to Xanthias Phoceus.

4. Return’d to Boston this morning— Mr: Briesler came with me as far as Mr: Gardner’s, who brought me the rest of the way.— Found my child a little better than when I left home on Saturday— Day at my office. Mr: Quincy called upon me, and assured me in most explicit terms that he had long since determined not to suffer himself to be held up as a candidate for the district at this election— Adding his entire satisfaction at seeing my name introduced to the public for that station— I shall therefore say no more upon the subject. Transacted some business with Mr: Marston, & Mr: Jackson— Paid Mr: Marshall his Judgt: vs Orrok— Walk’d in the Mall at the beginning of the Evening; and spent the rest of it at home.

5. Day at my Office— Court of Common Pleas, opens this day— Received a letter this afternoon from Mr: Bridge— Sold J. Jackson a bill of exchange on Bird, Savage, & Bird, in favour of Mr: Joy. In the evening, walk’d in the Mall, and wrote to my brother.

6. Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy with Miss Morton; and returned in the evening. I spent the day at my Office— Writing in the forenoon, and reading Dr: Belknap’s American biography in the afternoon— Walk’d in the Mall, and pass’d the evening at home.

7. Morning partly at my Office, and partly attending on the Court of Sessions, hearing an argument between Mr: Sullivan and Mr: Blake concerning a new road to be laid out in Hingham— The Court appointed a Committee to view— In the afternoon I read the lives of Bradford, Cushman and Brewster in Belknap’s biography, and spent the Evening at home, writing, after a walk in the Mall.
8. Court of Common Pleas sat, and I attended them.— At my Office the remainder of the day— Finished the numbers of Lalius.— Walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home—pass’d it in literary idleness.

9. Principal part of the day at my office. Took two depositions as a Commissioner with W. Sullivan, for the Supreme Court at New-York. Bought some Union Bank Stock of J. Jackson— In the afternoon I went out to Quincy, with W. Shaw— Mrs: Adams and the family did not go, because Mrs: Johnson expects to leave us next week, on her return to Washington— Wrote to Mr: King— Gave the letter to Mr: Babcock, to be carried by Mr: G. Higginson.

10. Read two treatises of Plutarch— Upon the question when and how a man may decently speak of himself, and a fragment upon the infirmities of body & soul. Also some parts of Horace, and a few of Made de Sevigné’s letters— Her son, who writes incomparably well recommends to his sister the Treatise of Plutarch, upon the distinction between a flatterer and a friend.— The weather being very warm I bathed this morning— Heard Mr: Whitney— Spent part of the evening at Mr: Cranch’s— Captain Charles Apthorp was there with his brother— He has been with the british army in Egypt— His opinion of General Hutchinson as an Officer, I think is not great— He says the business was done before he had the command— So indeed Hutchinson has said himself.— Mr: W. Cranch sets out on Thursday.

11. Return’d to Boston with Mr: Shaw early this morning.— Mr: Nolen called upon me— I went with him, and looked over the house he offers for sale— Agreed to give him 7250 dollars for it; if I find the title secure— Business of various kinds in the course of the day— Evening at home reading and writing.

12. Walk in the Mall before breakfast, and again at the beginning of the evening. Remainder of the day at my Office, and attending at the Court of Common Pleas— Mrs: Johnson was to have gone this afternoon out to Quincy, and to proceed on her journey from thence— But Mr: Cranch with whom she intends to go, call’d this afternoon to inform her he has concluded to go from Boston in the stage, and not to meet it on the way, from Quincy— So the carriage return’d empty— Wrote this Evening to my brother.

13. Attended at the Court of Common pleas, nearly the whole day. Signed an agreement with Charles Nolen, to purchase his house— The deed to be given the 7th: of next month. Drew up petitions against the proposed new road in Quincy. Sent one out to Captain Beale, by Mr: D. Greenleaf— Walk’d in the Mall, and spent the evening at home— Mr: Cranch called to arrange with Mrs: Johnson, for going to-morrow morning.

14. At 4 o’clock this morning Mrs: Johnson left us, and went with Mr: Cranch and his family to New-Bedford; to go from thence by water to New-York, and on to Washington— Attended at the Court of Common Pleas, and, at a sale of books, in the morning.— Dined at Mr: Babcock’s, with a company of men— Evening at home— Read to the ladies the first book of Paradise lost— Mr: Shaw out at Roxbury, the night.
15. Attended the whole day at the Court of Common Pleas, where there were two or three trials— Auction of furniture at Clap’s— Evening at home— Read the 2d: book of Paradise lost to the Ladies.

16. At the Court of Common Pleas all the morning, and at my office in the afternoon— Intended to have gone out to Quincy, but was prevented by heavy rains— Evening at home— Read to the ladies the third book of Paradise lost.

17. Heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury for Mr: Emerson— Mrs: Adams went in the afternoon and was unwell at church— Walk’d in the Mall, afterwards— Read a Sermon of Tillotson— The 6th: on holding fast the faith— In the evening read the fourth book of Paradise lost to the ladies.

18. Attended the Court of Common Pleas all day— The forenoon was spent in a small jury trial— In the afternoon I argued a motion for a new trial in the case of Saxton and Wainwright against Vinall— On the ground that at the trial last term one of the jurors had formed and expressed an opinion upon the merits before the whole evidence was produced.— The argument was not finished this afternoon, but adjourned over untill Wednesday morning— Walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home— Read the 5th: book of Paradise lost to the Ladies.

19. At ten O’Clock this morning, lieutenant Governor Robbins called and took me up— Went with him, Dr. Elliot and Mr: Emerson to Cambridge, as a Committee of the Overseers of the College, to attend at a quarterly exhibition, and hear a statement of the situation of the College, from the immediate Government.— I had not to my recollection before attended an exhibition before, since I left College myself— The performances were similar to those of that time— A brother of Mr: Kirkland’s was the English Orator— We afterwards met the College Government in the philosophy chamber— And their report of the state of the College was satisfactory— We all dined together at the Steward’s house— Mr: Plummer, newly chosen a Senator in Congress from New-Hampshire, and Mr: Andrews of Newbury-Port, dined with us.— In the afternoon we spent an hour in the library— Then went and took tea at the President’s, after which we return’d to Boston— Evening at home; and read the sixth Book of Paradise lost.

20. The Court of Common Pleas met at 9 this morning and sat till twelve— The new Circuit Court of the United States, Judge Cushing, & Judge Davis, met at twelve, and sat till 2. They adjourned untill to-morrow morning, and the Court of Common Pleas sat again at 3. in the afternoon.— Adjourned to next Tuesday. Club this Evening at Mr: Kirkland’s.— Has been interrupted several weeks, most of the members out of town.

21. Circuit Court sat again this morning— When pleas to the Jurisdiction were filed upon several continued actions, on the ground that the late Act of Congress altering the Jurisdiction was unconstitutional— The Court adjourned to the afternoon when a demurrer was filed to one of those pleas, and they adjourned again to hear the argument to-morrow.— Mr: Townsend dined with me.— Had some conversation with him upon his Swedenborgianism, in which he is far gone— J. Gardner spent an hour with me at my Office— Called at Dr: Welsh’s for Mrs: Adams and Caroline who had been there at tea, but they were returned home— Read the 7th: book of Paradise lost— Early to bed—

22. Attended the Circuit Court all day— The pleas to the Jurisdiction yesterday filed were withdrawn. And a trial commenced— A quitam action on the Statute against the slave trade— The trial was not gone through; but continued over for to-morrow— Evening at home— Read the 8th: and part of the 9th: book of Paradise lost— Mr: Shaw went this day to Quincy.

23. The trial begun yesterday was this day finished— The Court sat untill near four o’clock in the afternoon. Went, with Mrs: Adams, Caroline and the child out to Quincy.— I have expected letters from my brother, but find myself disappointed.

24. Read Plutarch’s precepts of Marriage. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham. Consulted Belknap’s biography, and Prince’s Chronology, for the subject upon which I am writing— I find it tedious and dry; and am dissatisfied with what I have written.

25. Return’d to Boston this morning, leaving Mrs: Adams and the family at Quincy— Transacted some business at the Union Bank; attended the Court, where there were several trials: to the Court in the forenoon; and to the Jury in the afternoon— J. Gardner dined with me— Evening at home writing.

26. Attended at the Circuit Court; a Case of perjury upon the bankrupt Act was tried— Dined with the Court at Mr: G. Blake’s— In the afternoon attended a meeting of the Historical Society, where little business was done— The trial in Court was resumed after dinner, and finished at about 7 in the evening. I pass’d the remainder of it at home— Mr: Andrews of Newbury-Port called on me this morning.

27. Attended at the Circuit Court in the forenoon— In the afternoon at the funeral of Mrs: Condy, our next door neighbour— Evening at the Club, at Mr: Quincy’s. The Court sat only for a few minutes in the afternoon.

28. The Circuit Court adjourned this day— Spent the afternoon at my Office— Reading Mourt’s relation in Purchas’s pilgrims— Walk in the Mall— Evening at home writing to my brother— Mr: Shaw dined at Mr: Mason’s.

29. Court of Common Pleas at length adjourn’d this day— Dr: Tufts and Mr: Pitts were at my Office. Spent the day principally there— Evening at home after walking in the Mall— Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy with Mr: White, and returned in the evening.

30. Attended a meeting of the proprietors of Middlesex Canal. A Question was made, whether it should be determined to stop at Mystic river, where they have at length arrived, or proceed with it to Charles River— The decision was to leave it in the discretion of the Directors, who were chosen at this meeting. Left the meeting before it dissolv’d, and went with Mr: Quincy to Quincy— Dined with a Company of Gentlemen there, who kept my father’s birth-day.— The company was about forty-five persons.— I left them soon after dinner, and pass’d the evening at home.

31. Read Plutarch’s banquet of the seven wise men— The most entertaining of the treatises I have yet found— Interspers’d with lively wit; characteristic observation and pleasant dialogue. Heard Mr: Whitney.— Evening at home— The weather foul and stormy.

Day— Rise between 6 and 7. in the morning— Write or read until 10. Breakfast— Attend at my Office, or at the Courts which have been sitting untill 2— Go home and dine— Return to my Office or the Courts, untill dark— Walk an hour— Rest of the Evening at home reading or writing— Sup at 10.
